trial_identification.studytitle: Ultrasound-guided transversus abdominis plane block versus caudal block for pain relief in children
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Ultrasound-guided transversus abdominis plane block versus caudal block for postoperative pain control in children undergoing groin surgery

interventions.interventions: Anesthesia will be induced with sevoflurane and followed by placement of a laryngeal mask airway. Then a single Ultrasound-guided transversus abdominis plane block will be administered with levobupivacaine 0.25% 0.4mL/kg
interventions.comparator: Anesthesia will be induced with sevoflurane and followed by placement of a laryngeal mask airway. Then a single caudal block be administered with levobupivacaine 0.25% 1mL/kg

primaryOutcome.timepoint: From the data of intervention until the data of the first registration of a CHIPPS scores larger than 3, assessed up to 24h

primaryOutcome.outcome: the number of patients not requiring rescue analgesia

secondaryOutcome.outcome:
Postoperative pain intensity
The quality of postoperative pain control was assessed by the Children and Infants Postoperative Pain Scale (CHIPPS)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: after surgery, 30min for first 4h, hourly for the next 4h and thereafter every 2h, assessed up to 24h

secondaryOutcome.outcome:
the incidence of emergence agitation
The incidence of emergence agitation was evaluated by the Pediatric Anesthesia Emergence Delirium Scale(PAED)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Participants will be followed for the duration of PACU stay, an expected average of 2 h.

secondaryOutcome.outcome:
Residual motor block
The degree of motor blockade was assessed using a modified Bromage scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: After awake,participants will be followed every 30min for the first 2h, hourly for the next 4h

secondaryOutcome.outcome:
the sedation score
Sedation was assessed using the Modified Ramsay Sedation Score
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: After surgery,every 15min for the first 2 h and every 30min for the next 2h.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Side effects including bradycardia, hypotension, hypoxemia, nausea, vomiting and urinary retention
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: From the administration of the transversus abdominis plane / caudal block until the end of study period, assessed up to postoperative 24h

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: ASA ststus I-II aged 2-5yr undergoing unilateral inguinal hernia repair
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Hypersensitivity to any local anesthetics Infections at puncture sites Bleeding diathesis Preexisting neurological disease

trial_design.concealment: Allocation was concealed by sealed opaque envelopes that were opened by a nurse not involved with the care of the individuals.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation by using a randomization table created by a computer software

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: No.134 Dongjie Street, Fuzhou, Fujian, China, 350001

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Caudal block (CB) is the gold standard technique for analgesia in children undergoing surgical interventions in the groin.
Although the efficacy and the safety of this technique is high, nonetheless, there are several caveats such as unwarranted motor blockade of the lower limbs and disturbances of the bladder function, potentially resulting in delayed demission in the ambulatory setting.
An alternative method to block neural structures which innervate lower abdominal wall has been described: the transverse abdominal plane block. The ultrasound guided technique improves the safety of margin.
However, although this new technique seems to offer substantial advantages so far only experience from small case series are available. In particular, the TAP block has not been compared in a systematic trial with the "gold standard", the caudal block.
The aim of this study is to evaluate potential differences in the effectiveness of postoperative analgesia and to test the hypotheses that the duration of pain relieve is prolonged after a TAP block when compared with an epidural caudal technique.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Medical Ethics Committee of Fujian Provincial Hospital
ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: No.134, Dongjie Street, Fuzhou, Fujian, China,350001
